thread.title: Washington County judge who stopped doing weddings to retire
thread.title_full: Washington County judge who stopped doing weddings to retire | OregonLive.com

author: Emily E. Smith | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Washington County judge who stopped doing weddings to retire
text:
Washington County Circuit Judge Thomas Kohl will retire at the end of the year, Oregon Gov. Kate Brown announced in a statement Wednesday.
Gov. John Kitzhaber appointed Kohl, a former city attorney, to the Washington County bench in 1997. His Dec. 31 retirement comes about a year before his current term expires.
During his tenure, Kohl has previously served as presiding judge, and in 2005 he launched the county's Drug Court program, which offers treatment and reduced sentenced for selected chronic drug offenders. He continues to preside over drug court.
Kohl's 21-year-old daughter was fatally stabbed in a murder-for-hire plot in 2006. Her killer, Robert Bettelyoun , was convicted of aggravated murder in 2009 and is serving life in prison without parole.
Kohl has written a book and speaks to audiences in prisons and churches about his transformative experience with faith, and how it enabled him to forgive his daughter's killer.
In September, Kohl said he had stopped performing wedding ceremonies as a judge after a federal judge overturned the state's gay marriage ban last year.
"Last summer for personal faith-based reasons, I decided to not perform weddings as a judge," he said.
He declined to answer questions about the decision, saying, "This is a personal choice based on my faith."
Gov. Brown, in a statement Wednesday, thanked Kohl for his service. She is accepting applications to fill his position. Interest forms are due Nov. 9.
